thread.title: Stalled Transition: Burkina Faso’s Fading Chance for Reform
thread.title_full: Stalled Transition: Burkina Faso’s Fading Chance for Reform

author: info@worldpoliticsreview.com (Peter Dörrie)
title: Stalled Transition: Burkina Faso’s Fading Chance for Reform
text:
People protesting against the military's coup attempt among the burnt out remains of tires, Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, Sept. 17, 2015 (AP photo by Theo Renaut). Stalled Transition: Burkina Faso’s Fading Chance for Reform Peter Dörrie Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2015 
Hailed at the time as the start of an “African Spring,” the October 2014 revolution that ousted President Blaise Compaore in Burkina Faso was called into question last month when an elite army unit staged a brief coup. But even before soldiers under the command of Gen. Gilbert Diendere derailed the transition, the process was in many ways already disappointing. Now the coup’s failure has opened another window of opportunity for real democratic progress, but serious questions over the likelihood of true reform remain.Many of Burkina Faso’s contemporary challenges are deep-rooted. Some of the country’s most important political figures today have shaped Burkinabe politics since the 1980s, and others grew up and became politically aware in their shadow. ... ×
